g:HTMLPanel.p: The sections below give detailed instructions on how to use the programs that make up Scansite.

The navigation bar on the left-hand side of this page allows you to navigate to all static sections in Scansite. The list below describes what pages clicking on the navigation buttons will bring you to.

tr.td: The Scansite 3 landing page ("Home") presents you with an overview of Scansite's features. You can either click on one of the links provided here, or navigate to these features by using the Scansite Features section in the navigation bar.
We will keep you up-to-date about changes to Scansite in this section of the page.
The features listed here are described in more detail below.

g:HTMLPanel.p: This program will scan a protein of your choice for all of the motifs in Scansite, for a subset of them, or for a motif you prepared and uploaded. You can either use a protein entry in public databases (SwissProt, TrEMBL, Genpept, Ensembl, Yeast), or your own protein sequence.

ol.li:
Select or enter a protein:
If you want to use a protein from a public database , select Protein Accession from the "Choose Protein By" listbox. Next, select a database and enter the protein's accession number/ID. For databases that provide multiple accession numbers or IDs for their entries, all of those should be found. To check if the protein is available in our database mirror, click the "Check!" button. The accession-field turns green if the protein exists, and red in case the entered string does not match any of our records. If you don't know the accession number or ID, you can use the links on this page ("Search ...").
You can also enter a protein sequence by selecting Input Sequence from the the "Choose Protein By" listbox. You will have to enter a protein name and copy/paste your sequence into the given input fields. If numbers, spaces, or other invalid characters are included in the sequence, Scansite will remove them.

Choose which motif(s) to scan. You have the following choices:
Choose All Motifs from the listbox labeled "Look for" to scan for All motifs in our database.
Choose Selected Motifs and Groups from the listbox labeled "Look for" to scan for only the motif(s) and group(s) you selected . Please select one or more motifs/groups here. If you select a group, all of the motifs that belong to that group will be included in your protein scan. However, you do not have to select a group. To see an overview of how motifs are categorized into groups, click the entitled "Show Group Definitions".
To use your own motif file, choose User Motif from the listbox labeled "Look for". You will be asked to choose the prepared file from your filesystem and to give your motif a descriptive name.

Choose a stringency level: high, medium, low, or minimum.
This sets how high a sequence must score when compared to all sequences that match the motif within the reference scoring proteome used (by default the entire vertebrate collection of SwissProt proteins) to be shown in the result list.
High stringency indicates that the motif identified in the query sequence is within the top 0.2% of all matching sequences contained in vertebrate SwissProt proteins. Medium and low stringency scores correspond to the top 1% and 5% of sequence matches, respectively. The choice of minimum sets the threshold to 15% , which basically allows most sites to pass. For uploaded motifs no reference proteome information is available. Therefore, a default score threshold of 5 is used.
Sites identified under high stringency scoring are likely to be correct, though there is a possibility that real sites will fail to be identified (i.e. a non-zero false negative selection rate). In contrast, medium, low, and minimum stringency scoring has a much lower rate of false-negative predictions, but tends to over-call motif sites, resulting in increasing numbers of false positive hits.

To show domains recognized in your sequence, check the box labeled "Show predicted domains". Otherwise, uncheck it. Scansite uses InterProScan to find a sequence's PFAM-domains. For this reason, the domain positions that are showed on the results page may differ slightly from domains the PFAM web page returns.

If you do not want to have your result sites compared to the default reference proteome (Vertebrates from Swissprot) you can check "Use Non-Standard Reference Proteome". This allows you to choose an alternative reference proteome: the Yeast Database.
Click "Submit" to start your protein scan!

g:HTMLPanel.p: When your protein scan has finished a Protein Scan Results-page will be displayed. This page is divided into these groups (you can hide each section by clicking on its title bar):

tr.td: This section will give you all the information about the given protein we have available in our database mirror. Usually this includes some description, keywords, and alternative accession numbers.
The scan overview section shows you the input parameters you chose for this protein scan and the number of predicted motif sites.

Your protein is shown here, drawn as a thin rectangle. If any sites were found, they are marked above the rectangle with a short-hand name of the domain type (in Scansite often called motif group , such as "Y_Kin", "SH2", or "PDZ"). If you requested domains in your sequence to be shown, they will be marked as colored boxes with their names and residue ranges annotated below the rectangle. Further down, a plot of the surface accessibility indicates residues that are likely to be near the protein surface and thus able to interact with other proteins. However, our surface accessibility is calculated from the sequence, and not with reference to any known structures, so its accuracy may be limited. Between these to plots, a simple ruler indicates every hundredth position in the sequence.

The table presented here shows all the predicted motif sites. You can sort the sites by selected columns (score, percentile, motif, group, site, sequence, and surface accessibility) by clicking on the table's header. Sorting by site will sort the sites by the positions in the sequence; sorting by sequence will sort the sites by the site's center position (usually s, t, or y). By default the sites are sorted by groups.
If the score-value is highlighted like a link, you can click it to have a histogram plot of the site within the reference proteome pop up in a separate browser window/tab. For Scansite motif scans (as opposed to input motif scans), the percentile displayed tells you the percentile that protein's score falls into compared with the selected reference proteome. The surface accessibility column tells you how accessible the sequence's position is to solvents (corresponds to the protein plot). Clicking on a link in the GeneCard-column takes you to that entry on the Gene Card website . The links in the sequence-column displays the full protein sequence with the site location highlighted in a new browser window/tab. The last column displays a link to phosphosite if the protein's site (e.g. T238) has an entry in PhosphositePlus . Please note that this reference is not motif specific, i.e. a Phosphosite-site that multiple motifs detected have the same link to Phosphosite! This feature is enabled for SwissProt proteins only at the moment.

If you want to repeat the scan with a different stringency value, you can select the stringency in this section and start the search right away. Apart from the stringency, the same parameters you used before will be used for your new protein scan.
You can download the results (as displayed in the table) in a file by using the link provided here.

ul.li: Most of the program execution time for Protein Scan is spent retrieving the Pfam domains. If you do not need domain information and have a lot of proteins to scan, you can save time by unselecting the "Show Predicted Domains" option.

If motifs you expect are not found in your protein at Scansite's default "High" threshold setting, try using the "Medium" or "Low" settings. The "Low" setting often overwhelms the graphical display unless you are scanning with a small number of selected motifs. However, even if the graphical display looks cluttered, the table of results is always easily readable (just longer).

Scansite scores are ranked on a 0 to infinity scale, where 0 means a protein sequence perfectly matches the optimal binding pattern, and larger numbers indicate progressively poorer matches to the optimal consensus sequence. Lower scores in the output are thus better matches. (In the matrices, higher scores are better, so you should still use higher numbers in self-made matrices to indicate high affinities.)

Clicking on the 15-residue sequence displayed in the results table shows the position of the site within the full protein sequence. Also, the page generated gives you a chance to submit this 15-mer peptide to BLAST. This can let you check whether this site's sequence is conserved in organisms expected to be physiologically similar to this hit.

If the sites found by Motif Scan seem believable, you can use the motifs for those sites to search databases for other hits. In favorable cases, this can allow you to piece together parts of a pathway, if the interacting parts of different proteins can be connected.

g:HTMLPanel.h3: Search a Sequence Database for Motifs
g:HTMLPanel.p: This program searches all proteins in a selected (subset of a) database for matches to a motif or a selection of motifs.

ol.li:
First of all, please select a "Search Method":
Choose Database Motif to search the database for occurrences of one Scansite motif. A listbox will be displayed that allows you to choose a motif.
Choose Input Motif to search the database for occurrences of your motif. You will have to choose a motif-file from your filesystem and enter a motif name. Detailed instructions about how to create a motif file are given on the FAQ page.
If you have insufficient information to make a full matrix of binding affinities, but you have a tentative consensus sequence describing your motif, you can still put this into Scansite and search the database for matches. Choose Quick Motif to use this option, and have the consensus sequence available so you can enter it.
Scansite will then construct a rough matrix matching the characteristics of your consensus sequence, and this can be used to search the databases. The results in this case will be less quantitative. However, many users have found this program useful for quickly finding proteins with certain sequence characteristics.
On the page there are two rows of small text boxes, labeled as positions -7 to +7, with 0 being the required fixed position. Start by entering your fixed residue in the only box at position 0. In the primary preference row (top one), enter the residues of your consensus sequence in their position relative to your fixed residue. You can also enter more than one residues in any text box ("ST", for example). Some wildcards are allowed too (they are described on the page). Scansite will give residues in the top row a score of 9.0. For positions with no residue preference, leave it blank or use "X" (any residue).
In the secondary preference row (bottom one), you can enter alternative residues at some positions if desired. These will be given a lower score of 4.5, and thus allows you to specify a weaker affinity for some residue types.
You can also search for proteins that match Multiple Motifs . Since this method is incredibly computationally expensive, the search limits you to a maximum of 5 motifs. You can combine your own motifs with scansite motifs if you want. Just select or/and upload motifs and choose a restriction method for your search. Your options are Gap Penalty and Strict Distance Bounds . Using a gap penalty is much faster than specifying strict distance bounds, because it only evaluates a proteins best scoring motif sites, whereas the other method evaluates all combinations of sites that are found.
A high gap penalty adds a penalizes distances between motif sites more than a medium one, and so on.
If choose to use strict distance bounds, you can specify up to three bounds. Please be aware that you have to select the motifs you want to use before you can choose them from the listboxes in this section. Only distance bounds between distinct motifs are permitted, i.e. you have to select two distinct motifs for specifying a bound.
Select the database to search using the specified motif(s).

If you are looking for proteins with specific characteristics, you can restrict the search to get a shorter list of more relevant results. Just click the links next to the input fields to get more information on what you are allowed to enter. If you do not want to specify any restrictions, you can leave all the restriction fields blank. Unrestricted searches can take a very long time, so we recommend you to restrict your search (especially if you choose to search one of the bigger protein databases: TrEmbl, or GenPept).
Finally, select how many proteins you want to see in your output list. If you want to know ALL sites, just download the output file from the result page.

p.i: Please be aware that this program can take several minutes to run if you select one of the larger databases (TrEMBL, Genpept) or if you do not restrict your search at all. Therefore we recommend to restrict the number of proteins that are searched somehow.

g:HTMLPanel.p: When the search is finished the results will be displayed. This page is divided into these groups (you can hide each section by clicking on its title bar):

tr.td: This section sums up your search parameters.

Here, a few numbers that give you an overview of your results are displayed. This includes:
Total Number of Proteins in Database: The number of proteins that are available in the selected database (no restrictions applied).
Number of Proteins Returned by Search: The number of proteins used for the search (with restrictions applied). This is the number of proteins that are scanned for the given motif(s).
Number of Predicted Motif Sites Found: The total number of motif sites found. You will find all these motif sites in the text-file you can download at the bottom of the page. The table below only displays the top x sites (with x being the output-list size you chose). If you performed a multi-motif database search this entry will be replaced by the total number of single motif sites detected and the number of combined sites. Combined sites are combinations of single motif sites that meet the specified restrictions.
Median of Scores / Median Absolute Deviation (MAD) of Scores: Two statistical values that give you an impression of about how good/bad a score you are interested in is in comparison to the rest of the results.

The table presented here displays the top motif sites that Scansite predicts. The results are by default sorted by score, but you can also sort them by protein accession, molecular weight, isoelectric point, or site position by clicking on the column's header. Clicking the score will show a histogram of how good this score is relative to all proteins that were scored in the selected database or database subset that you searched. Clicking the ID or accession number will take you to this protein's entry in the database that was searched. The "Scan!"-link will take you to the Protein Scan page where you can directly scan the protein you selected for motifs.
You can download the results (ALL results, not just those that are displayed in the table) in a tab-separated file by using the link provided here.

g:HTMLPanel.h3: Find Sequence Matches in a Database
g:HTMLPanel.p: This program searches all proteins in a selected (subset of a) database for sequence patterns.

ol.li:
First of all, please select a "Search Method":
Choose Sequence Pattern(s) if you want to search a database for occurrences of up to five sequence patterns. Follow the instructions displayed on the page.
The alternative option, Regular Expression allows you to search for more complicated sequence patterns. Some examples are given when you select this option. For more information about regular expressions, please see our FAQ page.
Select the database to search using the specified motif(s).

If you are looking for proteins with specific characteristics, you can restrict the search to get a shorter list of more relevant results. Just click the links next to the input fields to get more information on what you are allowed to enter. If you do not want to specify any restrictions, you can leave all the restriction fields blank. Unrestricted searches can take a very long time, so we recommend you to restrict your search (especially if you choose to search one of the bigger protein databases: TrEmbl, or GenPept).

p.i: The runtime of your search is highly dependent on the size of the database you chose. It can take up to several minutes if you select one of the larger databases (TrEMBL, Genpept) or if you do not restrict your search at all.

g:HTMLPanel.p: When the search is finished the results will be displayed. This page is divided into the following groups (you can hide each section by clicking on its title bar):

img.alt: Results of a sequence match database search

tr.td: This section sums up your search parameters and tells you how many proteins and sequence matches have been found.

The table presented here displays the all proteins that match the sequence patterns you were looking for. The results are by default sorted by protein accessions/IDs, but you can also sort them by the numbers of matches per pattern. Clicking the accession number will take you to a protein's entry in its database.
You can download the results (ALL results, not just those that are displayed in the table) in a tab-separated file by using the link provided here.

g:HTMLPanel.h3: General Notes and Hints for Restricting Scansite Searches (Database Search / Sequence Match)

img.alt: Tips for restricting searches (here: database search)

ul.li: The search options in this and the other Scansite database programs are intended to address common problems with database searches. For many searches, you may only be interested in matches from humans or a model organism. Restricting your search to proteins from a single species is done by entering that species name in the "Single species" text box. Scansite uses a MySQL database, and the regular expressions syntax supported by MySQL allows certain helpful wildcards. For example, if you are tired of writing out "Caenorhabditis elegans", you can use "C.* elegans" instead. In a regular expression, the period (.) matches any single character, and the asterisk extends that match to multiple characters (or even zero characters). You could also do genus-wide searches, by entering "Rattus" for example. If you try doing that with "Mus", you will accidentally match "Ther mus aquaticus" as well, but you can avoid that by entering "^Mus". The caret symbol (^) requires the text to match at the beginning of the entered name. Another pitfall to avoid is specifying an invertebrate species like "Drosophila melanogaster" when your Organism Class setting is "Mammals". You will get no hits, because no entry in Genpept has a source organism that is both a mammal and a fruit fly. (At least, the Genpept curators hope no entry like that is present.)

The molecular weight, isoelectric point, and phosphorylation options are intended for use in conjunction with two-dimensional gel electrophoresis experiments. When you find a few spots appearing reproducibly on a 2D gel under a particular test condition and not under the control, you could use Scansite to find what proteins are expected to be in that region of the 2-D gel by putting in a molecular weight range and isoelectric point. You could simultaneously constrain the species to match the cell line you used in the experiment. If it is an experiment involving possible phosphorylation events, you can see how much a putative phosphorylation would move it on the gel.

The keyword search is primarily only useful for searching Swiss-Prot, because of its detailed annotations. It might be useful in Genpept if you are searching for novel proteins, in which case you could search for phrases like "hypothetical".

The "Sequence contains" text field is a quick way to restrict your search to proteins containing a consensus sequence. Please note that the desired consensus sequence does NOT need to be part of the motif being searched for. Regular expressions have to be used here instead of the protein wildcard signs ("." instead of "X", "[ND]" instead of "B",...). For example, the sequence "PXXP" is represented as "P..P" in regular expression syntax. More details about regular expressions are given on the "FAQ" page.
